Brandon_Jenkins_(musician):

[[Josh Abbott Band]] | website = {{URL|brandonjenkins.com}} }} }} '''Brandon Dean Jenkins''' (June 7, 1969 – March 2, 2018) was an American singer-songwriter and philanthropist. He was part of the [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt]] music genre.{{cite news|last1=Little|first1=Tonya|title=Brandon Jenkins: Austin to Nashville|url=http://www.reddirtnation.com/View-Article/AID/3158|work=Red Dirt Nation|date=March 21, 2016|access-date=29 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228033707/http://www.reddirtnation.com/View-Article/AID/3158|archive-date=2016-12-28|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|last1=Wenger Watson|first1=Julie|title=Brandon Jenkins Takes Red Dirt Digital with Blue Bandana|url=http://nodepression.com/interview/brandon-jenkins-takes-red-dirt-digital-blue-bandana|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|date=October 26, 2015|access-date=December 27, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228033414/http://nodepression.com/interview/brandon-jenkins-takes-red-dirt-digital-blue-bandana|archive-date=December 28, 2016|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Red dirt musician Brandon Jenkins dies following heart operation|url=http://newsok.com/red-dirt-musician-brandon-jenkins-dies-following-heart-operation/article/5585527|work=newsok.com|date=March 2, 2018}} Jenkins performed in the Texas and Oklahoma regions, and he toured Europe on several occasions.{{cite news|last1=Wooley|first1=John|title=Jenkins conquers Europe; Goodbye to Andy O|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/jenkins-conquers-europe-goodbye-to-andy-o/article_37cbfbed-9e74-54ff-aebe-6c1c37026c45.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=September 6, 2001}} He often played 150 shows per year and shared the stage with [[Sunny Sweeney]], [[Zane Williams]], [[Cory Morrow]], [[Deana Carter]], [[Pat Green]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[The Mavericks]], and [[Kevin Welch]].{{cite web|last1=MacNeil|first1=Jason|title=Brandon Jenkins: Biography & History|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/brandon-jenkins-mn0000511685/biography|publisher=[[AllMusic]]}} One of Jenkins' notable songs, "Refinery Blues," was a biographical ballad about growing up near the Sand Springs Line, an area where oil refineries abound near the [[Arkansas River]] tributary of the [[Mississippi River]]. Jenkins was also a philanthropist as a supporter of the Red Dirt Relief Fund, a non-profit organization that supports musicians from the Red Dirt family of artists who face financial hardship. == Early life == Jenkins was born in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], to parents Wilma Jenkins (née Linthicum) and Dean Jenkins, a popular Tulsa radio disc jockey on stations [[KTBZ (AM)|KELi]] (where he was known as Dean Kelly) and [[KMOD-FM]].{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=CD Review: Brandon Jenkins "Brothers of the Dirt"|url=http://newsok.com/cd-review-brandon-jenkins-brothers-of-the-dirt/article/3411096|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=October 23, 2009}}{{cite web|title=Tulsa Radio: KTOW AM and FM|url=http://tulsatvmemories.com/ktow.html|website=Tulsa Radio Memories}} In 1987, Jenkins graduated from [[Central High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma)|Central High School]] in Tulsa, where he was in the jazz band, sang in the choir, and taught himself guitar.{{cite news|last1=Braudrick|first1=Nicole L.|title=Western Soul: Brandon Jenkins Reinvents His Style|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/western-soul-brandon-jenkins-reinvents-his-style/article_719221c7-43c9-5fe6-b490-00ed78fb33a1.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=May 1, 1996}} In the 1980s, He attended [[Oklahoma State University]] in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma|Stillwater]].{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Brandon Jenkins at home with 'Brothers of the Dirt'|url=http://newsok.com/brandon-jenkins-at-home-with-brothers-of-the-dirt/article/3403122|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=September 23, 2009}} During his time at OSU, Jenkins made life-long friends with many of his long-term musical collaborators in the [[Red Dirt (music)|Red Dirt Music]] community, including [[Cody Canada]], [[Mike McClure]], [[Stoney LaRue]], and Bleu Edmondson.{{cite news|last1=Boydston|first1=Joshua|title=Branded|url=http://okgazette.com/2012/02/21/branded/|work=[[Oklahoma Gazette]]|date=February 21, 2012}} Jenkins' uncle was the [[Grammy Award]]-winning bass player, sound engineer, and producer, Gordon Shryock, who was known for his work with [[J. J. Cale]] and [[Leon Russell]], as well as [[Andrae Crouch]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Natalie Cole]], and [[Dwight Yoakam]].{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Oklahoma native Brandon Jenkins brings red dirt to home state for tonight's Blue Door show|url=http://newsok.com/article/5467579|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=December 18, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Wooley|first1=John|title=Gordon Shryock: Grammy Winner Is Home to Stay|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/gordon-shryock-grammy-winner-is-home-to-stay/article_29d137df-01ec-581b-8eda-9299d8f42143.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=February 26, 1989}} == Career == In the early 1990s, Jenkins got his start recording for the Alabama-based record label, Rainy Records.{{cite book|last1=Conner|first1=Thomas|editor1-last=Joyce|editor1-first=Davis D.|title=Alternative Oklahoma: Contrarian Views of the Sooner State|url=https://archive.org/details/alternativeoklah00joyc|url-access=limited|date=2007|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=978-0-806-13819-0|pages=[https://archive.org/details/alternativeoklah00joyc/page/n109 89]–90, 100, 104–105|chapter=Chapter 6: Getting Along: Woody Guthrie and Red Dirt Musicians|oclc=71222981}} In 2003, Jenkins moved from Oklahoma to [[Austin, Texas]], where he lived until 2015.{{cite web|title=Songwriter/Composer: Jenkins, Brandon Dean|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?page=1&blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&fromrow=1&torow=25&affiliation=BMI&cae=186810450&keyID=605623&keyname=JENKINS+BRANDON+DEAN&querytype=WriterID|website=[[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]]}}{{Dead link|date=October 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2005, Jenkins released ''Down in Flames'' and got a 3-year record deal for his Western Soul Records imprint to have his work distributed by [[RED Distribution|Sony/RED]]. The record came out on the [[Thirty Tigers]] label.{{cite news|title=Brandon Jenkins Signs Sony/RED Deal|url=http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20050215143804604&query=brandon+jenkins|work=Angry Country Magazine|date=February 15, 2005|format=Press release|access-date=December 30, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230092823/http://magazine.angrycountry.com/article.php?story=20050215143804604&query=brandon+jenkins|archive-date=December 30, 2016|url-status=dead}} In 2008, Jenkins released ''Faster Than a Stone,'' which featured Travis Fite and Stoney LaRue.{{cite news|last1=Sudhalter|first1=Michael|title=Brandon Jenkins – Faster Than A Stone|url=http://www.roughstock.com/news/2008/11/21326-brandon-jenkins-faster-than-a-stone|work=RoughStock|date=November 22, 2008}}{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Mark|title=Q&A with Brandon Jenkins: Austin transplant Brandon Jenkins channels Tulsa|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/austin-transplant-brandon-jenkins-channels-tulsa/article_949b92f2-3219-5a2a-bc0e-9961780c0eb7.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=November 26, 2008}} Jenkins' 2009 album ''Brothers of the Dirt'' was a collaboration with many Red Dirt and Texas country scene artists: [[Cody Canada]] ([[Cross Canadian Ragweed]]), [[Stoney LaRue]], [[Jason Boland & The Stragglers|Jason Boland]], and [[Randy Rogers]].{{cite news|last1=Moser|first1=Margaret|title=Brandon Jenkins|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2009-11-27/921312/|work=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|date=November 27, 2009}} The record was his first release on the independent label E1 Entertainment/Red Dirt Music Co.{{cite news|last1=Woods|first1=Eric|title=Red Dirt rebel Brandon Jenkins still churning out chart-toppers|url=http://lubbockonline.com/entertainment/2010-08-27/red-dirt-rebel-brandon-jenkins-still-churning-out-chart-toppers|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|date=August 27, 2010}} The song, "Out of Babylon," sung by Jenkins and Canada, was a tribute to [[9/11]], while the song, "Innocent Man," is a LaRue and Rogers contribution inspired by the [[John Grisham]] novel about [[Ron Williamson]], ''[[The Innocent Man: Murder and Injustice in a Small Town]].'' The song, "Blood for Oil," was a protest song that focuses on [[George W. Bush]]'s involvement with [[Iraq War]]. In 2011, Jenkins released a record he called ''Project Eleven,'' which was a digital only 11-track record released on the 10th anniversary of [[September 11 attacks|9/11]], with a single released on September 11, 2011. In 2015, Jenkins released the record, ''Blue Bandana,'' which was recorded over a period of two days in David Percefull's Yellow Dog Studios with a full band capturing a live sound in one day and the engineering and mastering done over the next day. The record was released in a digital only format, with a limited number of physical versions available. Also in 2015, Jenkins released ''Brandon Jenkins @ Radio Recorders,'' which he recorded for Pride Hutchison and Dale Lawton's Tulsa-based label, Explosive Records. The record was made in 2006 in the Southern California record studio called Radio Recorders. Since Jenkins' music was firmly in the Texas country genre, this record was held onto for release, some nine years later.{{cite news|last1=Wooley|first1=John|title=Explosive Sounds: Oklahoma native and Texas country artist Brandon Jenkins releases two albums recorded nine years apart|url=http://www.okmag.com/blog/2015/11/20/explosive-sounds/|work=Oklahoma Magazine|date=November 20, 2015}} Jenkins recorded ''The Flag,'' in 2016 which again with long-time collaborator, Dave Percefull. This was recorded in [[Wimberley, Texas|Wimberley]], Texas, in the [[Texas Hill Country]], and features Dony Wynn, Bukka Allen (son of [[Terry Allen (artist)|Terry Allen]]) on accordion, and Kim Deschamps on lap steel and dobro. In 2016, Jenkins moved from Austin to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where his career would be based from until his death in 2018. === Songwriting === Jenkins' song "My Feet Don't Touch The Ground" was featured on [[Pete Anderson]]'s 2003 ''A Country West of Nashville'' album. The song garnered him an Emerging Artists in Music Award.{{Cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/brandon-jenkins-1/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228032824/http://www.mtv.com/artists/brandon-jenkins-1/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 28, 2016 |title=Brandon Jenkins |publisher=MTV |access-date=December 29, 2016}} The song was placed 8th on the list of "The 50 Best Red Dirt Texas Country Songs" of the ''[[Dallas Observer]],'' and helped his career significantly.{{cite news|last1=McCarthy|first1=Amy|last2=Dearmore|first2=Kelly|title=The 50 Best Red Dirt Texas Country Songs|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/the-50-best-red-dirt-texas-country-songs-7055741|work=[[Dallas Observer]]|date=February 16, 2015}} Fellow Red Dirt artists Bleu Edmondson ("Finger on the Trigger") and [[Stoney LaRue]] ("Feet Don't Touch The Ground") recorded and performed songs written by Jenkins. The song, "Feet Don't Touch The Ground," was praised by [[KKCN]] as being one of the top 5 recorded songs by [[Stoney LaRue]],{{cite news|last1=Stubbs|first1=Tommy|title=Top 5 Songs Ever Released By Stoney LaRue|url=http://103kkcn.com/top-5-songs-ever-released-by-stoney-larue/|publisher=[[KKCN]]|date=July 24, 2012}}{{cite book|last1=Hessman|first1=Jake|title=The Road Goes on Forever|date=2010|publisher=iUniverse|location=Bloomington, IN|isbn=978-1-4502-3906-6|pages=272–273|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eL33O_fpfLwC&q=brandon+jenkins|chapter=The Music}} and features on his album ''Live at Billy Bob's Texas''. His song "Down in Flames," co-written by [[Stoney LaRue]], appeared on ''[[The Red Dirt Album]]''. One of Jenkins' notable songs, "Refinery Blues," was a biographical ballad about growing up near the Sand Springs Line, an area where oil refineries about the [[Arkansas River]] tributary of the [[Mississippi River]]. The song describes the devastating effect the refineries and their pollutants had on generations of families in the area. In addition to writing hits for several of his fellow "brothers of the dirt," Jenkins had songs at the top of the Texas Music Radio Charts.{{cite web|title=Texas Music for the Country – Chart: August 13, 2007|url=http://www.texasmusicchart.com/Pages/Chart.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814011905/http://www.texasmusicchart.com/Pages/Chart.htm|archive-date=August 14, 2007|date=August 14, 2007}} == Influences == Jenkins cited the influence of the "[[Tulsa Sound]]" of [[J. J. Cale]] and [[Leon Russell]] on his songs and said that the songwriting gives him the most satisfaction.{{cite news|last1=Dufour|first1=Florent|title=Interview: Brandon Jenkins|url=http://facm.free.fr/interjenkins.htm|work=French Association of Country Music (FACM)|year=2002|language=fr}} Jenkins also cited the life and music of [[Woody Guthrie]] as being an important part of his approach to music and focusing on people and their lives in the Oklahoma region. == Personal life == Jenkins went by the nickname of Red Dirt Legend.{{cite news|last1=Poet|first1=J.|title=Brandon Jenkins: "Blue Bandana"|url=http://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/brandon-jenkins-blue-bandana/|work=Lone Star Music Magazine|date=December 24, 2015}} He was married to Michele Angelique Jenkins until his death in 2018. Jenkins was a supporter of the Red Dirt Relief Fund, a non-profit organization that supports musicians from the Red Dirt family of artists who face financial hardship.{{cite news|title="Stand" Song Project benefits RDRF|url=http://www.reddirtrelieffund.org/blog/stand/|work=Red Dirt Relief Fund|date=April 1, 2014|format=Press release}}{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Red Dirt Rangers and all-star lineup of Oklahoma musicians recording song for Red Dirt Relief Fund|url=http://newsok.com/red-dirt-rangers-and-all-star-lineup-of-oklahoma-musicians-recording-song-for-red-dirt-relief-fund/article/3946875|work=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=March 25, 2014}} On February 21, 2018, Jenkins was hospitalized in Nashville and underwent surgery to replace his [[aorta]] and [[aortic valve]].{{cite web|url=http://newsok.com/red-dirt-musician-brandon-jenkins-dies-following-heart-operation/article/5585527|title=Red dirt musician Brandon Jenkins dies following heart operation|publisher=NewsOK|date=March 2, 2018|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} After the procedure, he experienced surgical complications and remained hospitalized until his death on March 2, 2018, at the age of 48.{{cite web|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/scene/music/red-dirt-music-artist-brandon-jenkins-dies/article_56755311-848a-5d8d-a7b5-0a74bc8e473f.html|title=Red dirt music artist Brandon Jenkins dies|publisher=Tulsa World|date=March 2, 2018|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Title ! Album details ! Reference |- ! scope="row"| ''Faded'' | * Release date: April 13, 1996 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings |{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/3482861-Brandon-Jenkins|title=Brandon Jenkins Discography|publisher=discogs|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} |- ! scope="row"| ''The Ghost of Jesse James'' | * Release date: August 8, 1999 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''Live at the Blue Door'' | * Release date: 2000 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''Unmended'' | * Release date: 2002 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''Down in Flames'' | * Release date: April 5, 2005 * Label: [[Thirty Tigers]] | |- ! scope="row"| ''VII'' | * Release date: 2006 * Label: Smith Entertainment | |- ! scope="row"| ''Faster Than A Stone'' | * Release date: 2008 * Label: Smith Entertainment | |- ! scope="row"| ''Tough Times Don't Last'' | * Release date: July 2008
(originally released in February 1994) * Label: Smith Entertainment | |- ! scope="row"| ''Brothers of the Dirt'' | * Release date: 2009 * Label: E1 Music | |- ! scope="row"| ''Under The Sun'' | * Release date: 2011 * Label: Smith Entertainment | |- ! scope="row"| ''I Stand Alone'' | * Release date: May 2014 * Label: Red River Entertainment | |- ! scope="row"| ''Blue Bandana'' | * Release date: February 16, 2015 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''Brandon Jenkins @ Radio Recorders'' | * Release date: June 22, 2015 * Label: Explosive Records | |- ! scope="row"| ''Glass House Sessions'' | * Release date: August 12, 2015 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''The Flag'' | * Release date: April 5, 2016 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- ! scope="row"| ''Tail Lights in a Boomtown'' | * Release date: February 8, 2018 * Label: Red Dirt Legend Recordings | |- |} === Contributions === * 2003: Various Artists, ''A Country West of Nashville'' (Little Dog) – "My Feet Don't Touch the Ground"{{cite news|last1=Weiss|first1=Neal|title=Various Artists – A Country West of Nashville|url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/various-artists-country-west-nashville|work=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]|issue=46|date=June 30, 2003|access-date=December 29, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230161544/http://nodepression.com/album-review/various-artists-country-west-nashville|archive-date=December 30, 2016|url-status=dead}} * 2006: Various Artists, ''Red Dirt Sampler: Volume II. Songs in the Spirit of Woody Guthrie'' (CD Baby) – "Refinery Blues," also Producer{{cite news|last1=Wooley|first1=John|title=Release of 'Red Dirt Sampler' to benefit Guthrie festival|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/release-of-red-dirt-sampler-to-benefit-guthrie-festival/article_25682335-ab24-5a89-8b25-69c1c7913bcb.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=June 21, 2005}} * 2006: ''Route 66: Songs of the Mother Road'' (CD Baby) – "Headin' Down That Mother Road"{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/songs-of-the-mother-road-mw0001563856|title=Route 66: Songs of the Mother Road|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=March 2, 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{URL|brandonjenkins.com}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jenkins, Brandon}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Oklahoma]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from Texas]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Central High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma) alumni]] [[Category:Oklahoma State University alumni]] [[Category:Country musicians from Texas]] [[Category:Country musicians from Oklahoma]] [[Category:Musicians from Tulsa, Oklahoma]]
